title: Instantiating SuperRare DAO Governance
body:
In August, we announced the [SuperRare DAO](https://docs.superrare.com/the-superrare-dao) and launched the [$RARE curation token](https://superrare.mirror.xyz/fkGKcN1xVNRvfZk5OiY52-T_WNSndC4ve1DPDmvZQ6E), a fundamental metamorphosis of the platform that set SuperRare on a course for true community stewardship.

The announcement of the DAO came alongside several other foundational platform shifts, dubbed SuperRare 2.0. In the past two months, laying the groundwork for the underlying product, engineering and organizational transformation to come has been our main focus - and weâ€™ve begun publishing articles regarding our [philosophy](https://superrare.mirror.xyz/M9A9TbTMBkDD_No3Q0-LPjnq4OZxfDgxXKqBVLYRVDA) around decentralized governance and its [rollout](https://superrare.mirror.xyz/F9rkh2IxAo7YVB7W8MUNu3ocaGwpVsL1w28Kycwfkbw).

Now, weâ€™re excited to be at the stage where the rubber is hitting the road. Yesterday we shared some updates regarding the Space Race in Discord, and weâ€™re publishing that info here today for wider circulation.

All applications for Space Race #1 are IN! A whopping 35 amazing [applications](https://forum.superrare.com/t/space-race-1-submit-space-race-proposals-here/31) were submitted, exceeding our wildest expectations for interest in operating a Space. A follow-up email with an update on our thinking behind the race in light of the high turnout was sent to all applicantsâ€“if you were supposed to receive an email but didnâ€™t, let us know in Discord (#space-race). Weâ€™re targeting November 15th for the start of the first race ğŸ.

During todayâ€™s meeting with the governance council, Council member John Crain (CEO of SuperRare Labs) proposed two changes to the mechanics of the Space Race from the way it was initially published, to better satisfy the spirit of this first Space Race:Â 

1. The large number and high quality of applications for Space Race #1 led us to believe that allowing more than one Space per race to be elected by the community would result in a more successful overall process - and would be less likely to cause frustration among what is sure to be an ever growing list of applicants who take the time to submit such comprehensive proposals. As a result, we proposed increasing the number of winners for the first space race from one to many.
2. We also proposed that the Space Race voting interface switch from Snapshot to Mirrorâ€™s [Token Race](https://dev.mirror.xyz/dLLIq4Iebg5DLWJbOWa3sU6oQuwbogkmqPnz-ZbzPUg), a brand-new, open source voting interface that wasnâ€™t yet live when we announced the Space Race. We love the Token Race because it provides a live leaderboard, a cleaner UI, and is designed to allow for multiple winners per race.

A formal proposal of all mechanics of the Space Race will be discussed and developed by the council over the next week. If approved by the council, the Space Race governance framework will be put to a community vote to be ratified by $RARE holders, marking the moment when the DAO officially formalizes the mechanics of this first decentralized curation mechanism on SuperRare.

The council is also finalizing a draft DAO Charter - the document which formalizes the relationship between the council and token holders- which will serve as an operating constitution outlining the Councilâ€™s formal authorities in the near term. For example, the Charter will outline what types of proposals can be made by community members, and what decision making power the Council is granted by the community. This document will be shared at forum.superrare.com and submitted for a public vote when the final draft is ready to be considered and ratified by the DAO.

As governance operations ramp up, we as a community are going to be using the #governance Discord channel to share more information and discussion around both the Space Race and broader governance topics. 

Stay tuned for further updates!

title: Wealth in China
body:
As of 2020, China was second in the world, after the [US](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States), in total number of billionaires and total number of millionaires, with 698 Chinese billionaires and 4.4 million millionaires.[\[338\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-356)[\[339\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-357) In 2019, China overtook the US as the home to the highest number of people who have a net personal wealth of at least $110,000, according to the global wealth report by [Credit Suisse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_Suisse).[\[340\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-358)[\[341\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-359) According to the [Hurun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurun) Global Rich List 2020, China is home to five of the world's top ten cities ([Beijing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing), [Shanghai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai), [Hong Kong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong), [Shenzhen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shenzhen), and [Guangzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou) in the 1st, 3rd, 4th, 5th, and 10th spots, respectively) by the highest number of billionaires, which is more than any other country.[\[342\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-:17-360) China had 85 female billionaires as of January 2021, two-thirds of the global total, and minted 24 new female billionaires in 2020.[\[343\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-361)

However, it ranks behind over 60 countries (out of around 180) in per capita economic output, making it an upper-middle income country.[\[344\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-362) Additionally, its development is highly uneven. Its major cities and coastal areas are far more prosperous compared to rural and interior regions.[\[345\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-363) China brought more people out of extreme poverty than any other country in history[\[346\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-364)â€”between 1978 and 2018, China reduced extreme poverty by 800 million. China reduced the extreme poverty rateâ€”per international standard, it refers to an income of less than $1.90/dayâ€”from 88% in 1981 to 1.85% by 2013.[\[347\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-:1-365) According to the World Bank, the number of Chinese in extreme poverty fell from 756 million to 25 million between 1990 and 2013.[\[348\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-366) The portion of people in China living below the international poverty line of $1.90 per day (2011 [PPP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity)) fell to 0.3% in 2018 from 66.3% in 1990. Using the lower-middle income poverty line of $3.20 per day, the portion fell to 2.9% in 2018 from 90.0% in 1990. Using the upper-middle income poverty line of $5.50 per day, the portion fell to 17.0% from 98.3% in 1990.[\[349\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-367)

### Economic growth

*For Economic history of China, see [Economic history of China before 1912](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_before_1912), [Economic history of China (1912â€“1949)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)), and [Economic history of China (1949â€“present)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_history_of_China_(1949%E2%80%93present)).*

China's nominal [GDP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_Domestic_Product) trend from 1952 to 2015

From its founding in 1949 until late 1978, the People's Republic of China was a Soviet-style centrally [planned economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planned_economy). Following Mao's death in 1976 and the consequent end of the [Cultural Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_Revolution), [Deng Xiaoping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping) and the new Chinese leadership began to [reform the economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_reform_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China) and move towards a more market-oriented [mixed economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixed_economy) under one-party rule. [Agricultural collectivization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_farming) was dismantled and farmlands privatized, while foreign trade became a major new focus, leading to the creation of [Special Economic Zones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_Economic_Zone) (SEZs). Inefficient [state-owned enterprises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government-owned_corporation) (SOEs) were restructured and unprofitable ones were closed outright, resulting in massive job losses.\[*[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)*\] Modern-day China is mainly characterized as having a market economy based on private property ownership,[\[350\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-english.eastday-368) and is one of the leading examples of [state capitalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_capitalism).[\[351\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-369)[\[352\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-370) The state still dominates in strategic "pillar" sectors such as energy production and [heavy industries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heavy_industry), but private enterprise has expanded enormously, with around 30Â million private businesses recorded in 2008.[\[353\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Ref_abf-371)[\[354\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Englishpeopledailycomcn2005-372)\[*[betterÂ sourceÂ needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS)*\][\[355\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Ref_2005a-373)[\[356\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Ref_abg-374) In 2018, private enterprises in China accounted for 60% of GDP, 80% of urban employment and 90% of new jobs.[\[357\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-375)

In the early 2010s, China's economic growth rate began to slow amid domestic credit troubles, weakening international demand for Chinese exports and fragility in the global economy.[\[358\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-376)[\[359\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-377)[\[360\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-378) China's GDP was slightly larger than Germany's in 2007; however, by 2017, China's $12.2 trillion-economy became larger than those of Germany, UK, France and Italy combined.[\[361\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-379) In 2018, the IMF reiterated its forecast that China will overtake the US in terms of nominal GDP by the year 2030.[\[362\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-380) Economists also expect China's middle class to expand to 600 million people by 2025.[\[363\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-381)

In 2020, China was the only major economy in the world to grow, recording a 2.3% growth due to its success in taming the coronavirus within its borders.[\[364\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-382)

### China in the global economy

Share of world GDP (PPP)[\[365\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-383)YearShare19802.32%19904.11%20007.40%201013.89%201818.72%

China is a member of the [WTO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization) and is the world's largest trading power, with a total international trade value of US$4.62Â trillion in 2018.[\[366\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-384) [Its foreign exchange reserves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_exchange_reserves_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China) reached US$3.1Â trillion as of 2019,[\[367\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-385) making its reserves by far the world's largest.[\[368\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Ref_2009b-386)[\[369\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-387) In 2012, China was the world's largest recipient of inward [foreign direct investment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment) (FDI), attracting $253 billion.[\[370\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-FDI-388) In 2014, China's foreign exchange remittances were $US64 billion making it the second largest recipient of remittances in the world.[\[371\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-389) China also invests abroad, with a total outward FDI of $62.4Â billion in 2012,[\[370\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-FDI-388) and a number of major takeovers of foreign firms by Chinese companies.[\[372\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-390) China is a major owner of [US public debt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_public_debt), holding trillions of dollars worth of U.S. [Treasury bonds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treasury_bond).[\[373\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Ref_abe-391)[\[374\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Hornby2009-392) China's undervalued exchange rate has caused friction with other major economies,[\[242\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-CurrencyManipulator-260) and it has also been widely criticized for manufacturing large quantities of [counterfeit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterfeit) goods.[\[375\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-393)[\[376\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-394)

Largest economies by nominal GDP in 2018[\[377\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-395)

Following the 2007â€“08 financial crisis, Chinese authorities sought to actively wean off of its dependence on the U.S. dollar as a result of perceived weaknesses of the international monetary system.[\[378\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-396) To achieve those ends, China took a series of actions to further the [internationalization of the Renminbi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalization_of_the_Renminbi). In 2008, China established [dim sum bond](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dim_sum_bond) market and expanded the Cross-Border Trade RMB Settlement Pilot Project, which helps establish pools of offshore RMB liquidity.[\[379\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-397)[\[380\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-398) This was followed with bilateral agreements to settle trades directly in renminbi with Russia,[\[381\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-399) [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan),[\[382\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-400) [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia),[\[383\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-401) [Singapore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore),[\[384\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-massg-402) the United Kingdom,[\[385\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-403) and Canada.[\[386\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-404) As a result of the rapid internationalization of the renminbi, it became the eighth-most-traded currency in the world, an emerging international [reserve currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_currency),[\[387\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-igtop10-405) and a component of the IMF's [special drawing rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_drawing_rights); however, partly due to capital controls that make the renminbi fall short of being a fully convertible currency, it remains far behind the Euro, Dollar and Japanese Yen in international trade volumes.[\[388\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-406)

### Class and income inequality

*See also: [Income inequality in China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_inequality_in_China)*

China has had the world's largest middle class population since 2015,[\[389\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-407) and the middle class grew to a size of 400 million by 2018.[\[390\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-408) In 2020, a study by the [Brookings Institution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brookings_Institution) forecast that China's middle-class will reach 1.2 billion by 2027 (almost 4 times the entire U.S. population today), making up one fourth of the world total.[\[391\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-409) Wages in China have grown a lot in the last 40 yearsâ€”real (inflation-adjusted) wages grew seven-fold from 1978 to 2007.[\[392\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-410) By 2018, median wages in Chinese cities such as Shanghai were about the same as or higher than the wages in Eastern European countries.[\[393\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-411) China has the world's highest number of billionaires, with nearly 878 as of October 2020, increasing at the rate of roughly five per week.[\[394\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-:5-412)[\[395\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-:4-413)[\[396\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-414) China has a high level of economic inequality,[\[397\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-415) which has increased in the past few decades.[\[398\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-416) In 2018 China's [Gini coefficient](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gini_coefficient) was 0.467, according to the [World Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank).

title: Sociopolitical issues and human rights
body:
China uses a massive espionage network of cameras, facial recognition software, sensors, surveillance of personal technology, and a social credit system as a means of social control of persons living in China.[\[259\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-277) The [Chinese democracy movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_democracy_movement), social activists, and some members of the Chinese Communist Party believe in the need for social and political reform. While economic and social controls have been significantly relaxed in China since the 1970s, [political freedom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_freedom) is still tightly restricted. The [Constitution of the People's Republic of China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China) states that the "fundamental rights" of citizens include [freedom of speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_speech), [freedom of the press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press), the [right to a fair trial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_to_a_fair_trial), [freedom of religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_religion), [universal suffrage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_suffrage), and [property rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Property). However, in practice, these provisions do not afford significant protection against criminal prosecution by the state.[\[260\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-books.google-278)[\[261\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-hrw-279) Although some criticisms of government policies and the ruling [Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party) are tolerated, censorship of political speech and information, most notably on the Internet,[\[262\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-280)[\[263\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-AnonymousNoMore-281) are routinely used to prevent collective action.[\[264\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-282) By 2020, China plans to give all its citizens a personal "Social Credit" score based on how they behave.[\[265\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-283)\[*[needs update](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items)*\] The [Social Credit System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Credit_System), now being piloted in a number of Chinese cities,\[*[needs update](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items)*\] is considered a form of [mass surveillance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_China) which uses [big data analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_data_analysis) technology.[\[266\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-284)[\[267\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-285)

A number of foreign governments, foreign press agencies, and [NGOs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NGO) have criticized [China's human rights record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_China), alleging widespread [civil rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights) violations such as detention without trial, [forced abortions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forced_abortions),[\[268\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-286) forced confessions, [torture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torture), restrictions of fundamental rights,[\[195\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-freedomhouse-213)[\[269\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-XinBan2012-287) and [excessive use of the death penalty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China).[\[270\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-wp-288)[\[271\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-289) The government suppresses popular protests and demonstrations that it considers a potential threat to "social stability", as was the case with the [Tiananmen Square protests of 1989](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989).[\[272\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-290)

Western governments accused China of committing [genocide against Uyghurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uyghur_genocide) and detaining more than one million [Uyghurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uyghurs) and other [Xinjiang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xinjiang) minorities in camps.[\[273\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-291)

The Chinese state is regularly accused of large-scale repression and human rights abuses in [Tibet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_Tibet)[\[274\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-292)[\[275\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-293) and [Xinjiang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uyghur_genocide),[\[276\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-294) including violent police crackdowns and [religious suppression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_suppression) throughout the Chinese nation.[\[277\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-295)[\[278\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-296) At least one million members of [China's Muslim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam_in_China) [Uyghur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uyghurs) minority have been detained in [mass detention camps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xinjiang_re-education_camps), termed "Vocational Education and Training Centers", aimed at changing the political thinking of detainees, their identities, and their religious beliefs.[\[279\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-297) According to the [U.S. Department of State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State), actions including political [indoctrination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indoctrination), [torture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torture), [physical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_abuse) and [psychological](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_abuse) abuse, [forced sterilization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compulsory_sterilization), [sexual abuse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_abuse), and [forced labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unfree_labour) are common in these facilities.[\[280\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-298) The state has also sought to control offshore reporting of tensions in Xinjiang, intimidating foreign-based reporters by detaining their family members.[\[281\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-299) According to a 2020 report, China's treatment of Uyghurs meets UN definition of genocide,[\[282\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-300) and several groups called for a UN investigation.[\[283\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-301) On 19 January 2021, the [United States Secretary of State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State), [Mike Pompeo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Pompeo), announced that the [United States Department of State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State) had determined that "genocide and crimes against humanity" had been perpetrated by China against the Uyghurs.[\[284\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-wsj._U.S._says-302)

[2019â€“20 Hong Kong protests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Hong_Kong_protests)

Global studies from [Pew Research Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pew_Research_Center) in 2014 and 2017 ranked the Chinese government's restrictions on religion as among the highest in the world, despite low to moderate rankings for religious-related social hostilities in the country.[\[285\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-303)[\[286\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-304) The [Global Slavery Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Slavery_Index) estimated that in 2016 more than 3.8 million people were living in "conditions of modern [slavery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_China)", or 0.25% of the population, including victims of human trafficking, forced labor, forced marriage, child labor, and state-imposed forced labor. The state-imposed forced system was formally abolished in 2013, but it is not clear to which extent its various practices have stopped.[\[287\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-305) The Chinese penal system includes labor prison factories, detention centers, and re-education camps, which fall under the heading [Laogai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laogai) ("reform through labor"). The Laogai Research Foundation in the United States estimated that there were over a thousand slave labour prisons and camps, known collectively as the Laogai.[\[288\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-306)

In 2019, a study called for the mass retraction of more than 400 scientific papers on [organ transplantation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organ_transplantation_in_China), because of fears the organs were obtained unethically from Chinese prisoners. While the government says 10,000 transplants occur each year, a report by the [Falun Gong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falun_Gong)-linked IETAC alleged that between 60,000 and 100,000 organs are transplanted each year and claimed that this gap was being made up by executed [prisoners of conscience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prisoners_of_conscience).

title: Governance on Solana (DAO ğŸ¥²)
body:
## Inventory

 
 Solana has a built in Governance program.  As such itâ€™s not very usable, you need UI to interact with the contract conveniently. As such there is a Mango partnered instance of frontend, but anyone could build one (cf [Squads](https://squads.medium.com/))

* a back-office web app to create and manage DAO called [Oyster]() on GH, the [UI looks like this](). 
* a use-facing web app to allow access for voting and seeing governance proposals, called [governance-ui]() on GH, the [UI looks like this](). It has been built w/ Mango Market people, thatâ€™s the Mango DAO we know.

The back office does not allow the creation of DAO by anyone right now, but I imagine they have a tiny vetting process as to who can interact and getting in touch with them should allow a â€œlistingâ€.

## The Governance Primitive on Solana

Below is the diagram of the governance program. Iâ€™ll go through the documentation and add some comments. This is a personal notes kind of document.

![OCD level 120% at all the non-straight boxes and arrows](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/GgoZbyTtxztDLkSE_hV2d.png?height=1451&width=1304)

## Realm Account - The top level organisation

> **Realm account** ties Community Token Mint and optional Council Token mint to create a realm for any governance pertaining to the community of the token holders. For example a trading protocol can issue a governance token and use it to create its governance realm.

This is a top level thing that is like an internal DAO for the team, it can use the governance token, or a separate TeamGovernance token. I think using the governance one is fine, if there is a way to time lock it.

It represents the organisation, and from this you derive new `ProgramGovernance` instances, each of them managing ONE and only program.

## Governance Accounts - The controllers

### Program Governance Account - Program

> The basic building block of governance to update programs is the ProgramGovernance account. It ties a governed Program ID and holds configuration options defining governance rules. The governed Program ID is used as the seed for a [Program Derived Address](https://docs.solana.com/developing/programming-model/calling-between-programs#program-derived-addresses), and this program derived address is what is used as the address of the Governance account for your Program ID.
>
> What this means is that there can only ever be ONE Governance account for a given Program. The governance program validates at creation time of the Governance account that the current upgrade authority of the program taken under governance signed the transaction. Optionally `CreateProgramGovernance` instruction can also transfer `upgrade_authority` of the governed program to the Governance PDA at the creation time of the Governance account.

You deploy your program, and then transfer the authority to the governance account. (?)

This then provide an API for upgrades.

*I wonder how the upgrade goes, what are the limitations like update size if it needs to fits CPI calls?*

### Mint Governance account - Mint 

> A mint governance account allows a mint authority to setup governance over an SPL Mint account. The Governance program validates at creation time that the current mint authority signed the transaction to create the governance and optionally can transfer the authority to the Governance account. Once setup the Mint Governance allows governance participants to create Proposals which execute mint instructions for the governed Mint.

Similar logic as the Program Governance Account above, except the API is tailor to cater for Minting needs.

### Token Governance account - SPL Token Account (wallet)

> A token governance account allows a token account owner to setup governance over an SPL Token account. The Governance program validates at creation time the current owner signed the transaction to create the governance and optionally can transfer the owner to the Governance account. Once setup the Token Governance allows participants to create Proposals to execute transfer instructions from the governed token account.

Similar to the PGA and MGA above, except itâ€™s a SPL wallet API this time.

## Authority

### Proposal accounts

> A Proposal is an instance of a Governance created to vote on and execute given set of instructions. It is created by someone (Proposal Owner) and tied to a given Governance account and has a set of executable instructions to it, a name and a description. It goes through various states (draft, voting, executing, ...) and users can vote on it if they have relevant Community or Council tokens. Its rules are determined by the Governance account that it is tied to, and when it executes, it is only eligible to use the [Program Derived Address](https://docs.solana.com/developing/programming-model/calling-between-programs#program-derived-addresses) authority given by the Governance account. So a Proposal for Sushi cannot for instance upgrade the Program for Uniswap.

This is the actual Proposal submitted to the public for voting. But before it goes liveâ€¦ â¤µï¸

> When a Proposal is created by a user then the user becomes Proposal Owner and receives permission to edit the Proposal. With this power the Owner can edit the Proposal, add/remove Signatories to the Proposal and also cancel it. These Signatories can then show their approval of the Proposal by signing it off. Once all Signatories have signed off the Proposal the Proposal leaves Draft state and enters Voting state. Voting state lasts as long as the Governance has it configured to last, and during this time people holding Community (or Council) tokens may vote on the Proposal. Once the Proposal is "tipped" it either enters the Defeated or Succeeded state. If the vote can't be tipped automatically during the voting period but still reaches the required Yes vote threshold it can be manually transitioned to Succeeded state using FinalizeVote instruction. Once all Proposal instructions are executed the Proposal enters Completed state.

This explain the several stages of a proposal, itâ€™s to prevent indirect rugs like team member X votes to transfer all the treasury to his wallet with lowest treshold and vote himself.

> In the Executing state an instruction can be run by any one at any time after the `instruction_hold_up_time` period has transpired

This is for time-lock and vesting, nice.

_____ 
  
 TL:DR; for the last bits is that a `ProposalAccount` can have several `ProposalInstructions`, the actual pieces of work (send X tokens to Billy - Update the program with his patch). If that interest you I think youâ€™ll go in [the doc]() and check the voting dynamic that I havenâ€™t mentioned here. All what I talked about is from there anyway. 
 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/06rBmfJZt-Fh0Enc8H2W5.png?height=1490&width=1775)

## Respect my authority, how does it all come together

So usually, a team would have control over the Program deployment, Minting of its IDOâ€™d {gov/shit}coins, and control the wallet(s) (IDO profits, fees, communityâ€¦).

This is a big responsibility, because upgrading the program on Solana means changing its behaviour silently. Any project with control of the Program Deployment can just send an TX to suck your NFT the next time you transact without doing a forensic analysis of the TX prompt if they want, and the confirmation UI/UX is not always super clear (quite good on Phantom now though)

I wonâ€™t speak about Mint and Wallet unilateral control, which is straight forward about the involved risks.

_____

To overcome that, the governance above is a great tool, the important bit being :

> Governance can handle arbitrary executions of code.

In the example above, letâ€™s say the team delegates Program Deployment, Mint and Wallets to the DAO. Then is mean that the only way they have to interact with these is to to submit proposals and get them approved.

Letâ€™s say they want to pay a bug bounty, then they craft the TX with the amount and in/outs, then send it to the `TokenGovernanceAccount` (not sure about the exact flow but you get the idea) and it will be there waiting to reach a treshold of vote or the timeout for the program to decide wether it should pass (be signed by it's Authority) or be rejected.

Gov token holder go on the aforementioned UI and vote with their stake. On given proposals.

______

Itâ€™s an indirection layer that prevents bamboozles, with supplementary indirection-ception. 

It can feel a bit useless, as usually the teams/investors/whales own a large chunk of the tokens, and could band up to do bad things? But itâ€™s what a governance is, people who have stake decides. Thatâ€™s the base rule.

Whatâ€™s valuable here is that least we got it fully transparent and immuable, thanks to the blockchainâ„¢ï¸. We know who did what and when.

title: Imperial China
body:
The [Warring States period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warring_States_period) ended in 221Â BCE after the [state of Qin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qin_(state)) conquered the other six kingdoms, reunited China and established the dominant order of [autocracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autocracy). [King Zheng of Qin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_Zheng_of_Qin) proclaimed himself the [First Emperor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Emperor) of the [Qin dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qin_dynasty). He enacted Qin's [legalist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legalism_(Chinese_philosophy)) reforms throughout China, notably the forced standardization of [Chinese characters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_characters), [measurements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_units), road widths (i.e., cart axles' length), and [currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Chinese_currency). His dynasty also [conquered the Yue tribes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qin%27s_campaign_against_the_Yue_tribes) in [Guangxi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangxi), [Guangdong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong), and [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam).[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-74) The Qin dynasty lasted only fifteen years, falling soon after the First Emperor's death, as his harsh authoritarian policies led to widespread rebellion.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Bodde1986-75)[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Lewis2007-76)

Following a [widespread civil war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chu%E2%80%93Han_Contention) during which the imperial library at [Xianyang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xianyang) [was burned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_destroyed_libraries#Human_action),[\[p\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-78) the [Han dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_dynasty) emerged to rule China between 206Â BCE and CEÂ 220, creating a cultural identity among its populace still remembered in the ethnonym of the [Han Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_Chinese).[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Bodde1986-75)[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Lewis2007-76) The Han [expanded the empire's territory considerably](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Han_dynasty), with military campaigns reaching [Central Asia, Mongolia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han%E2%80%93Xiongnu_War), [South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gojoseon%E2%80%93Han_War), and [Yunnan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_campaigns_against_Dian), and the [recovery of Guangdong and northern Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southward_expansion_of_the_Han_dynasty) from [Nanyue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanyue). Han involvement in Central Asia and [Sogdia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sogdia) helped establish the land route of the [Silk Road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silk_Road), replacing the earlier path over the [Himalayas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himalayas) to India. Han China gradually became the largest economy of the ancient world.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-79) Despite the Han's initial decentralization and the official abandonment of the Qin philosophy of [Legalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legalism_(Chinese_philosophy)) in favor of [Confucianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confucianism), Qin's legalist institutions and policies continued to be employed by the Han government and its successors.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-80)

Map showing the expansion of [Han dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_dynasty) in the 2nd century BC

After the [end of the Han dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End_of_the_Han_dynasty), a period of strife known as [Three Kingdoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Kingdoms) followed,[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-81) whose central figures were later immortalized in [one](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms) of the [Four Classics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Classics) of [Chinese literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_literature). At its end, [Wei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cao_Wei) was swiftly overthrown by the [Jin dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(265%E2%80%93420)). The Jin fell to [civil war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_the_Eight_Princes) upon the ascension of a [developmentally disabled emperor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_Hui_of_Jin); the [Five Barbarians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Barbarians) then [invaded](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uprising_of_the_Five_Barbarians) and ruled northern China as the [Sixteen States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sixteen_Kingdoms). The [Xianbei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xianbei) unified them as the [Northern Wei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Wei), whose [Emperor Xiaowen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_Xiaowen_of_Northern_Wei) reversed his predecessors' apartheid policies and [enforced a drastic sinification on his subjects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_and_Southern_dynasties#Northern_dynasties), largely integrating them into Chinese culture. In the south, the general [Liu Yu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_Wu_of_Liu_Song) secured the abdication of the Jin in favor of the [Liu Song](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liu_Song). The various successors of these states became known as the [Northern and Southern dynasties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_and_Southern_dynasties), with the two areas finally reunited by the [Sui](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sui_dynasty) in 581. The Sui restored the Han to power through China, reformed its agriculture, economy and [imperial examination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_examination) system, constructed the [Grand Canal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Canal_of_China), and patronized [Buddhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhism_in_China). However, they fell quickly when their conscription for public works and a [failed war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goguryeo%E2%80%93Sui_War) in [northern Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goguryeo) provoked widespread unrest.[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-82)[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-83)

Under the succeeding [Tang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tang_dynasty) and [Song](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_dynasty) dynasties, Chinese economy, technology, and culture entered a golden age.[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-84) The Tang Empire retained control of the [Western Regions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Regions) and the Silk Road,[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-85) which brought traders to as far as [Mesopotamia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesopotamia) and the [Horn of Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horn_of_Africa),[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-86) and made the capital [Chang'an](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chang%27an) a cosmopolitan urban center. However, it was devastated and weakened by the [An Lushan Rebellion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/An_Lushan_Rebellion) in the 8th century.[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-87) In 907, the Tang disintegrated completely when the local military governors became ungovernable. The Song dynasty ended the [separatist situation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Dynasties_and_Ten_Kingdoms_period) in 960, leading to a balance of power between the Song and [Khitan Liao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khitan_Liao). The Song was the first government in world history to issue paper money and the first Chinese [polity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polity) to establish a permanent standing navy which was supported by the developed shipbuilding industry along with the sea trade.[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-88)

A detail from *[Along the River During the Qingming Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival)*, a 12th-century painting showing everyday life in the [Song dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_dynasty)'s capital, [Bianjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bianjing) (present-day [Kaifeng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaifeng))

Between the 10th and 11th centuries, the population of China doubled in size to around 100 million people, mostly because of the expansion of rice cultivation in central and southern China, and the production of abundant food surpluses. The Song dynasty also saw a [revival of Confucianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Confucianism), in response to the growth of Buddhism during the Tang,[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-89) and a flourishing of philosophy and the arts, as [landscape art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landscape_art) and [porcelain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porcelain) were brought to new levels of maturity and complexity.[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-90)[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-91) However, the military weakness of the Song army was observed by the [Jurchen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jurchen_people) [Jin dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(1115%E2%80%931234)). In 1127, [Emperor Huizong of Song](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emperor_Huizong_of_Song) and the capital [Bianjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bianjing) were captured during the [Jinâ€“Song Wars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jin%E2%80%93Song_Wars). The remnants of the Song retreated to [southern China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_and_southern_China).[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-92)

The 13th century brought the [Mongol conquest of China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_China). In 1271, the [Mongol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongols) leader [Kublai Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kublai_Khan) established the [Yuan dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuan_dynasty); the Yuan conquered the last remnant of the Song dynasty in 1279. Before the Mongol invasion, the population of Song China was 120 million citizens; this was reduced to 60 million by the time of the census in 1300.[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-93) A peasant named Zhu Yuanzhang overthrew the Yuan in 1368 and founded the [Ming dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ming_dynasty) as the [Hongwu Emperor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor). Under the Ming dynasty, China enjoyed another golden age, developing one of the strongest navies in the world and a rich and prosperous economy amid a flourishing of art and culture. It was during this period that admiral [Zheng He](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zheng_He) led the [Ming treasure voyages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ming_treasure_voyages) throughout the [Indian Ocean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Ocean), reaching as far as [East Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Africa).[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-94)

The [Qing conquest of the Ming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_conquest_of_the_Ming) and expansion of the empire

In the early years of the Ming dynasty, China's capital was moved from [Nanjing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanjing) to Beijing. With the budding of capitalism, philosophers such as [Wang Yangming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wang_Yangming) further critiqued and expanded Neo-Confucianism with concepts of [individualism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individualism) and equality of [four occupations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_occupations).[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-95) The [scholar-official](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scholar-official) stratum became a supporting force of industry and commerce in the tax boycott movements, which, together with the famines and defense against [Japanese invasions of Korea (1592â€“1598)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_invasions_of_Korea_(1592%E2%80%931598)) and [Manchu invasions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_conquest_of_the_Ming) led to an exhausted treasury.[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-96)

In 1644, Beijing was captured by a coalition of peasant rebel forces led by [Li Zicheng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Zicheng). The [Chongzhen Emperor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chongzhen_Emperor) committed suicide when the city fell. The Manchu [Qing dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qing_dynasty), then allied with Ming dynasty general [Wu Sangui](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wu_Sangui), overthrew Li's short-lived [Shun dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shun_dynasty) and subsequently seized control of Beijing, which became the new capital of the Qing dynasty.

title: Early life
body:
Cher was born Cherilyn Sarkisian in [El Centro, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Centro,_California), on May 20, 1946.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200117-2) Her father, John Sarkisian, was an [Armenian-American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armenian_Americans) truck driver with drug and gambling problems; her mother, [Georgia Holt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_Holt) (born Jackie Jean Crouch), was an occasional model and bit-part actress who claims Irish, English, German, and [Cherokee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cherokee) ancestry.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-4) Cher's father was rarely home when she was an infant,[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParishPitts2003147-5) and her parents divorced when Cher was ten months old.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200117-2) Her mother later married actor John Southall, with whom she had another daughter, Georganne, Cher's half-sister.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200117%E2%80%9318-6)

Now living in [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles), Cher's mother began acting while working as a waitress. She changed her name to Georgia Holt and played minor roles in films and on television. Holt also secured acting parts for her daughters as [extras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extra_(actor)) on television shows like *[The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Ozzie_and_Harriet)*.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParishPitts2003147-5) Her mother's relationship with Southall ended when Cher was nine years old, but she considers him her father and remembers him as a "good-natured man who turned belligerent when he drank too much".[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200118-7) Holt remarried and divorced several more times, and she moved her family around the country (including New York, Texas, and California).[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParishPitts2003147-5) They often had little money, and Cher recounted having had to use rubber bands to hold her shoes together.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200118-7) At one point, her mother left Cher at an orphanage for several weeks.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBego200110-8) Although they met every day, both found the experience traumatic.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200118-7)

When Cher was in fifth grade, she produced a performance of the musical *[Oklahoma!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma!)* for her teacher and class. She organized a group of girls, directing and choreographing their dance routines. Unable to convince boys to participate, she acted the male roles and sang their songs. By age nine, she had developed an unusually low voice.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTECherCoplon199839-9) Fascinated by film stars, Cher's role model was [Audrey Hepburn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audrey_Hepburn), particularly due to her role in the 1961 film *[Breakfast at Tiffany's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breakfast_at_Tiffany%27s_(film))*. Cher began to take after the unconventional outfits and behavior of Hepburn's character.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200122-10) She was also inspired by [Marlene Dietrich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marlene_Dietrich), [Bette Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bette_Davis), and [Katharine Hepburn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katharine_Hepburn).[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-11) She was disappointed by the absence of dark-haired Hollywood actresses whom she could emulate.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200122-10) She had wanted to be famous since childhood but felt unattractive and untalented, later commenting, "I couldn't think of anything that I could doÂ ... I didn't think I'd be a singer or dancer. I just thought, well, I'll be famous. That was my goal."[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200121-12)

In 1961, Holt married bank manager Gilbert LaPiere, who adopted Cher (under the name Cheryl LaPiere)[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-13) and Georganne, and enrolled them at [Montclair College Preparatory School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montclair_College_Preparatory_School), a private school in [Encino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encino,_Los_Angeles), whose students were mostly from affluent families. The school's upper-class environment presented a challenge for Cher; biographer Connie Berman wrote, "\[she\] stood out from the others in both her striking appearance and outgoing personality."[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200121-12) A former classmate commented, "I'll never forget seeing Cher for the first time. She was so specialÂ ... She was like a movie star, right then and thereÂ ... She said she was going to be a movie star and we knew she would."[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200121-12) Despite not being an excellent student, Cher was intelligent and creative, according to Berman. She earned high grades, excelling in French and English classes. As an adult, she discovered that she had [dyslexia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyslexia). Cher's unconventional behavior stood out: she performed songs for students during the lunch hours and surprised peers when she wore a midriff-baring top.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cher#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerman200122-10) She later recalled, "I was never really in school. I was always thinking about when I was grown up and famous.

title: Demographics
body:
The [national census of 2010](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sixth_National_Population_Census_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China) recorded the [population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population) of the People's Republic of China as approximately 1,370,536,875. About 16.60% of the population were 14 years old or younger, 70.14% were between 15 and 59 years old, and 13.26% were over 60 years old.[\[486\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-505) The population growth rate for 2013 is estimated to be 0.46%.[\[487\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-506) China used to make up much of the world's poor; now it makes up much of the world's middle class.[\[488\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-507) Although a middle-income country by Western standards, China's rapid growth has [pulled hundreds of millions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_in_China)â€”800 million, to be more precise[\[489\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-508)â€”of its people out of poverty since 1978. By 2013, less than 2% of the Chinese population lived below the international poverty line of US$1.9 per day, down from 88% in 1981.[\[347\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-:1-365) China's own standards for poverty are higher and still the country is on its way to eradicate national poverty completely by 2019.[\[490\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-509) From 2009 to 2018, the unemployment rate in China has averaged about 4%.[\[491\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-510)

Given concerns about population growth, China implemented a two-child limit during the 1970s, and, in 1979, began to advocate for an even stricter limit of one child per family. Beginning in the mid 1980s, however, given the unpopularity of the strict limits, China began to allow some major exemptions, particularly in rural areas, resulting in what was actually a "1.5"-child policy from the mid-1980s to 2015 (ethnic minorities were also exempt from one child limits). The next major loosening of the policy was enacted in December 2013, allowing families to have two children if one parent is an only child.[\[492\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-511) In 2016, the one-child policy was replaced in favor of a [two-child policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-child_policy).[\[493\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-512) Data from the 2010 census implies that the [total fertility rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_fertility_rate) may be around 1.4, although due to under-reporting of births it may be closer to 1.5â€“1.6.[\[494\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-513)

According to one group of scholars, one-child limits had little effect on population growth[\[495\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Wang_Judge-514) or the size of the total population.[\[496\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Whyte-515) However, these scholars have been challenged. Their own counterfactual model of fertility decline without such restrictions implies that China averted more than 500 million births between 1970 and 2015, a number which may reach one billion by 2060 given all the lost descendants of births averted during the era of fertility restrictions, with one-child restrictions accounting for the great bulk of that reduction.[\[497\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-516)

The policy, along with traditional preference for boys, may have contributed to an imbalance in the [sex ratio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sex_ratio) at birth.[\[498\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-517)[\[499\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-Ref_2007a-518) According to the 2010 census, the sex ratio at birth was 118.06 boys for every 100 girls,[\[500\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-genderratio-519) which is beyond the normal range of around 105 boys for every 100 girls.[\[501\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-520) The 2010 census found that males accounted for 51.27 percent of the total population.[\[500\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China#cite_note-genderratio-519) However, China's sex ratio is more balanced than it was in 1953, when males accounted for 51.82 percent of the total population.
